participants.participant: Fulvio Conti, Chief Executive Officer and General Manager
Luigi Ferraris, Director of Accounting, Planning and Control Department

plist.p: Well, I think we can get started with a warm welcome, and a good morning to all of you, ladies and gentlemen for hosting here 2008 Results and Strategy Presentation. I will like to welcome members of our Board who are sitting here and a set of the auditors as well as to our friends coming from Madrid. Rafael Miranda and qualified members of the team of Endesa are present. And our Andrea Brentan from the Enels Madrid is also joining us and I shall extend my warm welcome to all of them.

Today we'll present our strong set of 2008 results, which I think are confirming Enel's ability to deliver growth even in an unfavorable economic and financial environment. Then I will take you through the key points of our 2009-2013 plan, which will end with a focus on major overall financial targets.

I'm pleased to say that together with Luigi and – we will be obviously taking with contributions from all of our Directors sitting in this room, all of the questions that you might be raising after the presentation.

I also like to remind you that we'll be extending an invitation for all of you in the near future for a follow-up presentation in which we will discuss individual operational performance in detail, including an Investor Day for renewables.
Let me first of all give you an overview on the initiatives we are taking to maintain our strategic progress and respond to the current environment. And I have that chart moving on.

With the final acquisition of the 25% remaining stake of Endesa, I think we have substantially completed the international expansion program, positioning ourselves as a worldwide integrated energy leader.

As we will continue to integrate Endesa assets in our portfolio, we now see greater scope for synergies, which you will see detailed later on this presentation and which will enhance our profitability in the next five years.

We've also incorporated our new renewable energy company, Enel Green Power. And we'll continue to strive for efficiency programs throughout the plans. Also, we have finalized into disposables of some of the assets that we have earmarked for sale, such as the Ofresid high voltage grid to Terna. I do expect cash to be received in April at the earliest and early May at the latest. And we now just receiving two offers for the low pressure gas pipelines, which we will be commenting.

Let me underline first of all that all of this has been achieved in a deteriorating economic and financial climate. And against this backdrop, maintaining the current A- / A2 rating is central to development of our strategy. Because this is enabling us to preserve our leadership position and to achieve what I consider key priorities for the Group over the next five years; consolidating existing assets, delivering strong results and maintaining financial stability.

Now let me say a few words about what Enel has become these days. With operations across Europe, Russia and the Americas, total installed capacity will be reaching 95 gigawatt, with about 60 million customer being served throughout. I believe Enel is a company of truly to national scope and influence.

The past year has been a transformational period for us. The big leap forward we have achieved with the acquisition of the remaining 25% of Endesa has confirmed our position as a major international integrated player.

Our expanded position enables us to leverage significant economies of scale and a well-diversified regulatory and technological profile. The progress we have made across all of our regions has positioned Enel as a company that can deliver strong results to shareholders, even on a challenging economic environment.

This footprint is key to remain competitive in the world energy arena. Furthermore, our portfolio benefits from a unique mix of assets and technologies, which means good balance between unregulated and regulated activities.

As far as the unregulated activities are concerned, Enel can rely on the technological and geographical diversification, focused on minimizing the Group risk profile. But also a well-balanced fuel mix, with nuclear at 13%, hydro and hydro renewables at almost 30%, coal at 27%, with balance mainly consisting of CCGTs and oil and gas open cycles. I think all of this, coupled with our ongoing hedging strategy allows us to expect solid cash flows for the coming years.

Let's now have a look at financial stability as a key priority. In response to a difficult microenvironment and a commodity price decline, we intend to implement initiatives to ensure our financial stability. In particular, we'll be focusing on the following three areas; increasing our cash flow generation through efficiency and CapEx optimization. Disposing of those strategic assets and minority stakes in growth business to support our balance sheet. Strengthening our capital structure through a combination of rights issue and a revised dividend policy.

To give you more detail, in this chart, I think you will see that we can generate additional 10 billion euros of cash flow in the period, which will be available for further debt containment and reduction.

Let me start with the cash flow generation level. Well, first let me tell you that in 2008, we have already achieved a target of €400 million versus 2006, a cost savings we committed to. But we have room to do more and we have programs to deliver more. This through ongoing projects which are obviously available for you in the annexes, if you want to dwell on this. And by the way, this is just Enel standalone prior to the integration of Endesa, which I think will continue to deliver synergies and implement others' efficiency programs.

In 2008, we launch a second wave of program aimed at increasing efficiency, mainly through cost savings and working capital optimization. We call this Zenith. And some of the major projects the improvement of this program are: workforce management, €50 million; ICT initiatives, €140 million; billing revisions, €120 million; clean organization, 130; maintenance and sourcing, 40; unbalance and reduction, 95. This just on the cost savings side. And all of these project will be follow through with individual presentation to all of you, to double prove that we commit and deliver.

On working capital, we'll be managing inventory for a reduction of 207 million. We'll optimize billing with added 200 million and we'll change and revise terms of payment throughout the organization to yield another €200 million of working capital reduction. With all of this, we'll be reaching almost 3 billion euros of additional cash flow by 2011 versus 2008.

As far as CapEx are concerned, you can see that from this chart, our plan investment program in the next five years have been revised. And this just to reflect the lower demand growth and a changing economic outlook worldwide. Yet the new plan will continue to pursue selective organic growth opportunities, which we see as primarily focused on the following areas.

In Italy, clean coal and gas in this freeing facilities, renewables and some initial nuclear initiatives. In Spain and Latam, CCGTs and renewables. In Slovakia and France, nuclear. In Russia, CCGTs and gas extraction. In networks, in all the areas where we are already present, we see opportunities to enhance service quality through technological improvements. All of this yielding fair results for us.
As far as maintenance investments are concerned, we'll not cut back on any project. But our spending will be reduced to improve efficiency and lower prices.

Let me move now to asset disposal. We are closely reviewing our portfolio to ensure that we remain focused on strategic assets going forward. We will consider the disposal of a number of non-strategic assets and minority stakes and growth businesses, which include the high-voltage grid that you have heard of. This will yield us about 1.2 billion and this will be cashed in late April and May.

We now looking at two offers that we have received for a majority stake in our gas distribution network. We will open negotiations to dwell on those two offers starting tomorrow. And I do expect to have an early closing for this deal.

As far as Enel Green Power is concerned, we have received interest from international infrastructure funds. We'll start discussion to finalize this sale and we're working towards concluding the deal by the end of the year.

We also have identified other assets, which are peripheral and less strategic to our business model, which I remind you is based on vertical integration in areas, where we're already present. We have initiated a disposal program for those assets as well. We will give you further details on the assets and the sale process in due course.

These are high quality assets. And we firmly believe that we will be finding suitable buyers at the right price. But you will bear with me, I cannot give you right now the names and address of those assets. The total of these planned disposals will amount to approximately €10 billion by 2010, which again will go entirely to net debt reduction.

Now let's have a look into the strengthening our capital structure. As I've described, we're undertaking asset disposal program against a backdrop of deteriorating economic and financial condition and also looking at stricter rating agencies parameters. Clearly, it will be a crucial element to the success of this program that we maintain a single A- / A2 ratings.

It is with this in mind that we have decided to promote a rights issue of eight billion euros to all of our shareholders. At this regard our Board of Directors yesterday resulted upon calling an extraordinary AGM to approve the right issues to be executed by the end of June, early July.

And let me also stress that the Italian Minister of Economy, a majority shareholder, has confirmed its interest to participate in this operation. And let me also conclude that we have an underwriting syndicate that has already been formed to guarantee the offering.

At the same time, we are revising our dividend policy from a stable 0.49 cents per share to a 60% payout on ordinary income. Starting from 2009 results, we do expect our dividend yield to remain in the top tier of the market. These two measures together will reinforce our financial position, will fortify the Company against market volatility and will set a sound platform for our future.

To sum up, while there are short-term challenges, our long-term priorities remain clear. We are committed to delivering attractive returns to shareholders, taking advantage of the opportunities created by our expanded international profile in our efficiency programs. This will permit to our Group reinforcing a strategic geographical position that will prompt us to seize opportunities for further organic growth as soon as the recession is over.
Now let me over to Luigi for commenting the 2008 results, and I'll be back.

Thank you, Fulvio. And good morning, ladies and gentlemen. I'm really pleased to report a very strong set of financial results today. But before going through into details, let me mention that the 2007 results have been adjusted to take into account the completion of the purchase price allocation process and the discontinuation of the Italian gas distribution business.

In the annexes, you will find all the relevant details. But now, let's have the look at the numbers. First, I'm going to give you a snapshot of some financial highlights, then I will take you through the 2008 financial results.

Group EBITDA increased by 45.5%, driven mainly by the consolidation of Endesa, as well as by the positive contribution of all the other divisions. Without the contribution of Endesa, EBITDA grew by almost 12%. Group net income grew by about 35% to almost €5.3 billion, also due to the effective tax rates decrease. Net debt has decreased to €49.9 billion, in line with our commitment to bring the level below €50 billion.
Now, starting from EBIT down to net income. EBIT increased by almost 41% driven by EBITDA improvements. Our net financial charges amount to €3.2 billion. This is the net effect of the following:

First, higher interest charges for €1.6 billion. This is mainly due to the result in net debt position following the acquisition of Endesa, OGK-5 and Muntenia. The comparison with 2007 is affected by the inclusion in the last year figures of €300 million relating to dividend distributed by Endesa.

Second, lower income resulting from differed value valuation of the Acciona put option for €102 million. The average costs of debt has been equal to 5.5%. The Group's tax rate fell from 33.1% to 9.2%, or 33.7% on a like-for-like basis. This was the results of the benefit coming from the 2008 financial low, which I have already explained at the nine months results presentation. The annexes will give you further details also on this.

But before going through the EBITDA evolution, let me explain that 2007 EBITDA has been reclassified in order to reflect the new organization of the Group. In particular, during 2008, we have transferred some operations from Generation and Energy Management Italy and the International Division, to the newly incorporated Enel Green Power. Moreover, we transferred some other operation including Endesa from the International Division, to the Iberia and Latin American division. In the charts you can see all the effects of such organizational changes on 2007 EBITDA.

Now let's move to our EBITDA evolution. The 45.5% increase in EBITDA has been the results not only of the consolidation of Endesa for 12 months, but also of the excellent operational performance of each division. I will just go through details of Generation and Energy Management Italy, Endesa, Russia and Enel Green Power. You will find details of all the other division in the annexes.

First, Generation and Energy Management Italy. The increase in the generation margin equaled €337 million, thanks to the following; €388 million higher generation margin due to the contribution of higher unit margin, higher volumes and better generation mix. This is was offset by minus €51 million lower margin in the ancillary service markets.

Additional items are €104 million of trading activities mainly due to trading of CO2, better shipping condition to third parties, trading on gas and power, partially offsets by a lower gas margin. €328 million due to the capital gain from the disposal of some idle assets to Dolomiti Energia, and minus €399 million, mainly due to the delta per value for €302 million on commodity and on the CFD with a single buyer and higher cost for external and intercompany sources.

But let me give you an update on our agent strategy, in particular on forward electricity sales. As far as Italy is concerned, we have hedged over 97% of our 2009 domestic production at 45% for all 2010 production at an average base load price equal to €80 per megawatt hour for 2009 and €84 per megawatt hour for 2010 related to retail prices to final customers, stood in the region of €85 per megawatt hour.

As far as Spain is concerned, we are 70% hedged for 2009 and 25% for 2010 at an average base load price of €60 per megawatt hour. In Slovakia, 2009 domestic production is almost 100% hedged, while we are already 27% for 2010, at an average price of €68 per megawatt hour for 2009 and 62 for 2010.

Let's now have a quick look at the fuel cost evolution in generation and energy management in Italy. Well, net of ancillary services in spite of a substantial rise of the average fuel cost, the unit margin in the domestic thermal generation market increased from €22 per megawatt hour to €23 per megawatt hour. This, of course, is the results of our forward sales and commodity hedging activities.

Before moving on to the following division, let me give you just a quick look at the Russian activities. First, let me remind you that EBITDA has been included in the results since the end of May. OGK-5 reported full year EBITDA of €153 million. That represents a 41% increase on a like-for-like basis versus last year. As you can see in the charts, the electricity price, net of capacity payment is up by 18% versus last year. This confirms that the liberalization process of the Russian market and the alignment of its prices to the European average level is progressing according to the government agenda.

Let's now focus on Endesa results. EBITDA for 100% of the Company totaled €6.9 billion, representing an increase of more than €500 million versus full year 2007. This growth has been boosted by a balance contribution of the Iberia operation and Latin America operation in particular.

In Iberia, growth has been obtained, thanks to 53% higher pool prices versus last year, 15% better thermal load factors versus the rest of the market and a more efficient commodity cost base, 40% lower than the average of the sector, sustained by better generation mix with a greater weight on nuclear and hydro capacity.
EBITDA growth of 3.7% is reporting, including the negative effect of Royal Decree on CO2 that I remind you, has been recorded for a total amount of more than €400 million.

In Latin America, higher power prices improved distribution margins and additional capacity boosted Endesa EBITDA by 17% increase on last year, nearly doubling the growth path during the first half of this year.
EBITDA growth of 17% is reported, including lower output and lower distribution revenues in Argentina, affected both by lower rainfall and inflation-linked increase in fixed cost.

Due to the recent events in this country, I would like to underline the limited exposure we have in terms of net attributable profits and total capital investment. We are talking about less than 1% on our total assets in both cases.

And now, Enel Green Power. EBITDA totaled €1.2 billion, representing a 20% increase on a like-for-like basis versus last year. This improvement is due to the contribution of €57 million from Italy, mainly driven by higher generation margin, partially offset by negative effect of energy incentives. €62 million from North America, due to the contribution of higher volumes and €51 million from South America, mainly the result of higher volumes produced in Panama, which has totaled €38 million of additional EBITDA.

As far as our net debt evolution is concerned, you see that overall net debt stands at €49.9 billion, net of the discontinued operation. The reduction of the debt is mainly due to the impact of extraordinary activities. In particular, the sale of Endesa Europe and Viesgo to E.On and the acquisition of further 22.6% OGK-5 and Muntenia.
2008 net ordinary cash flow was positive by about €200 million and we expect it to be even more positive this year. You can find all the relevant details about our liquidity profile in the annexes.
Thank you for you attention. And now I'll hand over to Fulvio Conti for the strategic plan 2009-2013.
Thank you, Luigi. As you just heard, 2008 results are confirmed that we are delivering a strategy that we initiated back in 2005.

In the meantime as we already commented, we are facing an economic and financial environment worldwide turning down, a dramatic deterioration that we need to take into account. And to counter this, we have outlined already key priorities in terms of financial stability.

Now, its time to move to the other major key areas of our interests. For consolidation and integration, the best practice transfers control of the whole value chain as well as upstream and mainstream integration in commodities, will be our top priorities.
We will also maintain our leadership position in our core markets, which I remind you are Italy, Iberia, Slovakia, Russia, Eastern Europe, Latam, renewables in our all our exiting geographies.

We will be making targeted investments as well as selective divestments, aim at maintaining our cost leadership in a vertical integrated business model. With about 60 million customers, service quality will continue to be a must. And we'll export the technological leadership that we have developed in Italy across the whole Group.

Renewables will continue to represent a strategic industry characterized by high growth rates and we intend to strengthen our footprint here, as you will hear later on. We will capitalize on the quality of our assets which are less dependent than the peers on subsidies and incentives, more resilient than others.
Moreover, we'll continue to promote new technologies, investing in particular in carbon capture and sequestration, hydrogen, solar and smart grids.

But before going into Italian operations, let me give you a base assumption underpinning our plan. This chart shows the commodity price and the electricity demand scenario on which we have based the strategy and targets to our plan.

In particular, as far as demand is concerned, we have assumed a material slowdown in 2009 in all of our key markets, while we do expect growth of gradual return from 2010 onwards. But thanks to the action that we'd taken, you will see that our margins will remain stable despite this general negative environment.

Moreover, I would like to underline that despite a collapse of electricity demand the last few months, our fuel mix coupled with a well-diversified customer base and our forward sales program allowed us to protect margins and achieve a consolidated EBITDA for the first two months of this year, higher than in 2008. Indeed our preliminary January and February results here to-date are showing an EBITDA of €2.5 billion versus €2.2 billion, with Endesa still consolidated at 67%.

Now let's have a look in Italian operations in more detail. On average we expect Italian electricity demand to grow by about 1% a year over the course of the plan in the next five years. This year we anticipated demand will be reduced by economic weaknesses and we forecast that demand grow will return from 2010 onward. That's already made clear.

As a consequence, we see competitors reconsidering their CCGT investments profile. And thus these technology are likely to suffer the largest impact from demand weakness. We confirm the soundness of our generation mix by the way, which is made up of hydro, coal and CCGT which burns a more competitive end for gas and which will give Enel – which is giving Enel a more efficient cost structure than our peers.

In light of all of this, our strategy for Generation and Energy Management division in Italy will be based on two key areas. We will continue our clean-coal conversion plan. Now I'm very proud to remind you that our state-of-the-art Civitavecchia plant is now in operation. The first group is moving forward quite nicely. Moreover by 2010, coal production will be 40% of our total generation mix, even without the contribution of the Porto Tolle plant, which we'll be striving to get up and running by 2014.

Developing our mid-stream strategy in gas sourcing is of particular importance to us. I confirm our commitment to the Porto Empedocle gasify unit, a capacity of about eight billion cubic meters, a total investment of about €600 million. We do not expect any major impact from the move to a payer as bit mechanism, while we're forecasting a gradual reduction in the contribution from the ancillary services.

Let me move to the domestic market. As you know the liberalization process of the Italian market has been completed in bulk electricity and gas sector. In this framework our strategy will be one of maintaining a leadership position by reaching close to nine million customers by 2013, reducing our cost-to-serve from 45 years to 24 years per customer by 2013, mainly by optimizing back office and improving on our quality standards. That's a lot of money to save.

We continue to serve retail markets with innovative commercial proposal to appeal customers and reduce churn rate to a bare minimum. You will hear starting from Sunday a new offer, which is going to be introduced by us to prove that point to the Italian retail market.

On domestic Infrastructure and Networks, we'll continue to be focused on cost leadership and technological innovation. This will go together with maintaining our high quality standards, which have been strengthened also by the completion of our digital-meter program.

Our average cumulative duration of interruptions per customer will go further down from the 56 minutes to 47 minutes in 2013. Our innovations such as development of the Smart Grid, which can also integrate electrical vehicles, public-lighting system based on LED technology and digital meters for gas will help to strengthen our leadership position. Moreover, this division will contribute almost 14 billion operating cash flow in the next five years.

Let's have a look at International division. First, key important areas are in this regard Slovakia and Russia. In Slovakia, despite the recent decrease in electricity demand, we still believe this market to remain tight in the medium term with a reserve margin lower than 15% before the operation of the new Mochovce plant will be available. As for Russia, the liberalization process is progressing as planned. Internal gross pricing are rising and this will be reflected ultimately in higher electricity price.

We are continuing to expand our nuclear activities in France by participating in the EPR project with a total investment of €400 million. And we are looking into the second EPR unit at Penly after the Flamanville, which we're working together with our friends in EDF.

Finally, in Romania we continue to invest to improve quality standards of the electricity grid and will continue to be focused on customer satisfaction by yielding very attractive returns on investments.

Few more words on Slovakia and Russia. In Slovakia, the investment for the completion of unit three and four of Mochovce nuclear plant is a key priority. It will allow us to allocate capacity constraints and strengthen our presence in the central region. In addition, we will reduce outages and optimize maintenance to maximize competitiveness of our generation fleet.

In Russia, we will be investing €2 billion, mainly in improving our generation mix by building two new CCGT plants for a total of 100 megawatts of new capacity, which will increase our margin as we will be replacing less efficient open-cycle units. And we'll continue to invest in the upstream gas.

By the way, we do expect to deliver first gas from Severenergia in 2010 and to ramp up its production of equity gas at 20% ownership, up to six billion cubic meters, a big production. And all of this will be feeding our combined-cycle plans into the Russian market, thus further increasing our marginalities. In the meantime, we're focused on significant efficiency programs. To sum up, I strongly believe Russia will continue to be a key market for Enel.

Let me move into Endesa. Endesa will pursue a leadership strategy in each of its key markets, developing organic growth in line with expected demand, and continue to invest in maintenance and quality standards. Therefore in line with current microeconomic conditions, over the next five years Endesa will invest a total of slightly in excess of €13 billion.

Despite this unfavorable economic environment, Endesa will preserve its margins, targeting an EBITDA level in 2010 in line with the very good results achieved in 2008. We will deliver this result focusing on operational excellence, efficiency and a major synergy plan, on which I will dwell on in a moment.

Moreover, Endesa's pipeline project in renewables will reinforce overall strategy of the Group in this field. More specifically, Spain will continue to remain a strategic market. In the medium term, we expect peninsula electricity demand to grow by about 1.7% per year on average. In this scenario, the reserve margin will be stable just below 20% with electricity prices remaining stable in the region of 45 to €50 per megawatt hour up to 2010.

In regulation, we see signs of positive developments. In July 2009, with the introduction of the tarifa Ultimo Recurso, final tariff for the unqualified customer, the market will conclude its path towards full liberalization. The government is committed by the way to solve also the structural debtor's issue.

As regard to generation, Endesa will keep its current leadership position through a more balanced generation mix in the mainland, thanks to an efficient investment plan in new CCGT capacity, amounting to 1.6 gigawatt and €0.7 billion. And new pump storage capacity, investing €250 million for around 400 megawatt capacity. And this will allow Endesa to catch market opportunities arising from the strong growth in renewables.

As regard to sales, Endesa will keep its current balance and leadership position. On the extra-peninsular system, where demand is growing at higher level than the peninsular system, Endesa will invest about €1 billion to develop one gigawatt of capacity, with a mix of CCGTs and fuel oil. Other investments will be done to ensure good level of service to its customers and they're in attractive regulatory framework.
In renewables, after the recent agreement with Acciona, Endesa can still rely on a pipeline of 7,000 megawatt of viable projects and a base of 800 megawatt uninstalled capacity.

Let's now move to distribution where the regulatory scenario is moving towards a RAB-based system, rewarding investments and quality. Endesa's adapting its investment plan in line with expected demand, while ensuring a good level of service to its customer base. Moreover, we do expect Endesa to implement the digital metering system over its entire network by 2015.

In Latam, I think Latam represents a strategic platform for growth for Endesa. And our EBITDA will continue to increase in the short and medium term. The macroeconomic environment is less gloomy than in other regions, God bless them. Most of the countries in this area are not deeply affected by the current economic crises, thanks to the successful economic policy implemented in recent years.

Hence we foresee average demand growth between four and 5% for the next five years. Most of these markets are basically tight and power price forecasts in the medium and long term are expected to guarantee satisfactory returns on investments. Moreover, regulatory frameworks are advanced, transparent and stable, providing stability and predictability for the medium and long term.

More than 80% of EBITDA coming from distribution belongs to companies that have completed or about to complete their tariff revisions with a four to five years horizon. Most countries, and mainly Chile, have implemented long-term generation pricing and contracting schemes. Endesa will invest in new capacity generation in Chile, about 700 megawatts of both thermal and renewables, in Columbia 400 megawatt hydro, in Peru 200 megawatt of gas, keeping its current leadership position in the area. In all of our operations we'll pursue maximum efficiency ratios, maintaining optimal quality-of-service levels and reducing grid losses.

As far as synergies are concerned, the acquisition of the further 25% of Endesa will allow us to accelerate the implementation of the synergy program and to enhance the final amount of 750 million per annum by 2012, indicated as a target on December 2007. More specifically, in 2008 we extracted synergies of €266 million, about €100 million higher than the original target.

Relevant projects which are part of this program, involving all relevant business areas are focused on distribution, generation and procurement. Moreover, other projects will be developed. And we are committing now to a new synergy target of at least €1 billion of savings by 2013.

Let me now move to Enel Green Power. Renewables will continue to play a very important role in the future of Enel's and Enel's Group. Across all of our markets, there are strong condition for growth fueled by incentive schemes and requests for reaching a general CO2 abatement in mass European countries. I'm also very comforted by the new energy program of the U.S. administration, aiming at boosting renewable industry in the U.S.A., for which Enel has a very solid head start.

In this industry, we can leverage on a unique mix of geographies and technologies, delivering not only growth but a strong cash flow from year one, which can also be used for shareholders' remuneration.

Our strategy here – I think our strategy is based on the deployment and new projects from our pipeline, some of which are already authorized. Growth will be mainly focused on wind, on which we will invest about €2 billion in the next five years, bringing us total capacity from 1.2 gigawatt in 2008 to 2.8 gigawatt in 2013.
In geothermal, we will add another 130 megawatt to our existing asset base, reaching 800 megawatt in 2013. This 20% increase will consolidate our world leadership in the geothermal field.

Let me now move to our overall financial targets to finish my presentation to you. I think the numbers projected in this chart are already affected by tougher conditions in terms of commodity price and electricity demand. But the initiatives we have taken such as those to strengthen our capital structure and to improve our efficiency are now boosting our cash flow and will protect us from the short-term challenges. But we also finally lay a robust platform for growth in the medium and long term. The targets we are setting here clearly show the benefits we are gaining from the Endesa transaction and we expect to drive earning growth through 2013 and beyond.
Well, thank you very much for the attention and we're now pleased to entertain any questions you might have.

Thank you very much. I remind you that we will be collecting questions not only here, but also from people who are lively connected from the web, which I thanks for staying with us, and also from people who logged in via phone call. Let's start from here. First question, Alberto?

Thank you. Good morning. Alberto Gandolfi, UBS. First of all, I wanted to ask you about, you've given 2010 and 2013, but I was wondering if we could have bit more clarity on – a sort of a normalized situation, given the macro environment for 2011? 2011 is the first year where you don't have much forward selling, so what do you expect in terms of EBITDA and net income then? And can you elaborate your underlying assumptions just, for instance, if we take the carry forward curve?

The second question is about – you have, I think, in Slide Six, you're talking about 68 billion of operating cash flow, which I understand is already post-tax. Now that is based on quite, let me say, probably aggressive long-term oil assumption of 83. Can you explain how you do the build-up to that? So what would expect for '11 and '12 as well for oil? And if we were to see oil at 50 from here to 2013 how would that look? How would that 68 billion change and how would you react to it? Would you cut CapEx?

Or – and the third question is about dividends. Sorry, that's the last one, I promise. On 60% payout, my personal view is that the visibility on dividend is going down. It isn't anymore a flexed dividend, which means that you're probably a bit more exposed to the power price and commodity evolution. So for instance, I hear you're assuming constant spark spread in Italy and in Spain, but if we are in a demand-induced oversupply and 2011 numbers are bad and you do the rights issue, is there a floor you can put to that dividend per share? Even if you disagree with this view of the world, but is there a floor you can put on the dividend? Or if we see a really bad net income then you will stick to 60% pay out? Thank you.

Alberto, you could have asked also, what happens if I die tomorrow? The world will be maybe less polluted. Several questions, I mean, very technical and I'm afraid I have to bother our audience over here with a different explanation. But in general, let me put this way, and then I'll ask Luigi to integrate the more precise answers on your individual questions. We have used our, let us say, common-sense approach to building our plan. We don't want to be seen as pessimistic or optimistic. We want to go straight into what we consider to be credible, in terms of commodity-price assumption, in terms of demand, we take stock of today's situation. But we're not saying gloom and doom forever. We're saying recession come and go. The only question if I would be exactly knowing when recession will go, obviously I will be making a lot of money but – and you as well. But we're taking the view that economic worldwide variables will start recovering into 2010. I think it's most economic assumptions of major institutions are purporting this case.

And as a consequence of this, we think that if you make a stress case of one event in 20 years or one event in 50 years, as some of the bankers over here in the room will know it, I think we are in the solid path of solid assumptions. And a solid assumption, looking at today's on commodity pricing, is going to tell you that as an inventory low. Low price in a certain given time reduce the level of investment, the level of investment reduce, ratify the supply side of the oil, the price goes up and therefore you have to expect this same phenomenon to occur. And I've seen this in my 40 years career many times.

That's why I believe that what we're giving you is real fact-of-life assumption, a solid assumption and we should stick into – we should stick to that. Now we also have run sensitivities. You would expect that to be our role, to check what happen if everything goes berserk.
